title: The Greek Crisis Explained in Under 3 Minutes

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with the Eurozone, according to the dinner party analogy?

options.label: D

options.text: Increase the value of its currency.

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease the value of its currency by printing extra money.

options.label: C
options.text: Keep the value of its currency stable.

options.label: B
options.text: It limits the ability of individual countries to control their own monetary policy.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the purchasing power of all countries.

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the debt burden of all countries.

options.text: Greece's economy was stronger than other European countries.

options.label: B
options.text: Greece's unemployment rate was lower than other European countries.

options.label: C
options.text: Greece was able to borrow money more easily.

options.label: B
options.text: Political reasons, as a symbol of determination to have peace on the continent.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the debt burden of countries.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the economic integration of the United States and the Eurozone?

options.label: A
options.text: The United States has a more decentralized system, while the Eurozone has a more centralized system.

options.label: B
options.text: The United States has a more integrated system, with financial transfers between states, while the Eurozone does not.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The United States has a more isolated economy, while the Eurozone has a more globalized economy.

options.label: A
options.text: They believe Greece's economy is too strong.

options.label: B
options.text: They believe Greece's unemployment rate is too low.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not feel a sense of unity with Greece and do not want to support Greek people with their tax dollars.

options.label: D
options.text: They believe Greece's debt burden is too high.

options.label: A
options.text: Greece's economy is strong, with low unemployment and a low debt burden.

options.label: B
options.text: Greece's economy is recovering, with decreasing unemployment and a decreasing debt burden.

options.label: C
options.text: Greece's economy is in a disaster, with high unemployment and a high debt burden.

options.label: D
options.text: Greece's economy is stagnant, with stable unemployment and a stable debt burden.

multiple-choice.question: How does the Eurozone's single currency affect countries with different economic needs?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows countries to implement their own monetary policies.

options.label: B
options.text: It limits the ability of countries to control their own monetary policies.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the purchasing power of all countries.

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the debt burden of all countries.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on the creation of the Eurozone?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a well-planned economic decision.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a mistake, as it did not take into account the different economic needs of participating countries.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a necessary step towards European integration.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a response to the economic crisis.

options.label: B
options.text: The paradox of identity and difference

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Because the ship's purpose remains the same

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: Because we are a collection of constantly changing aspects
